You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)

in O​(k​n2)𝑂𝑘superscript𝑛2O(kn^{2}) time and using O​(k​n)𝑂𝑘𝑛O(kn) space was firstly provided in .
The time complexity was improved in O​(k​n+n​log⁡n)𝑂𝑘𝑛𝑛𝑛O(kn+n\log n) by  and in O​(k​(n−k)+n​log⁡n)𝑂𝑘𝑛𝑘𝑛𝑛O(k(n-k)+n\log n) by 4.
Some similar results exist also for clustering problems.
The k𝑘k-median and k𝑘k-medoid problems are 𝒩​𝒫𝒩𝒫\mathcal{N}\mathcal{P} hard in 2D since .

is also 𝒩​𝒫𝒩𝒫\mathcal{N}\mathcal{P}-hard for 2D cases 8.
The 1D cases of k𝑘k-means are also solvable by a DP algorithm,
with a complexity in O​(k​n)𝑂𝑘𝑛O(kn) using memory space in O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) [ref]28. Similar results are available for variants of p𝑝p-center problems.
The p𝑝p-center problems minimize the radius of a ball, to cover all the points with p𝑝p such identical balls.
Contrary to the continuous version, discrete p𝑝p-center variant consider the additional constraint to have a discrete set of points as candidates for ball centers. It makes sense to consider the original points as such candidates for centers, as in [ref]16.
The dual of a Max-min p𝑝p-dispersion is similar to a min-max optimization as in p𝑝p-center problems.
Duality relations hold between p𝑝p-dispersion-Mm and p𝑝p-center problems
in 1D and in tree structures: p𝑝p-dispersion-Mm is the dual of the continuous (p−1)𝑝1(p-1)-center for such cases .

The discrete and continuous p𝑝p-center problems are 𝒩​𝒫𝒩𝒫\mathcal{N}\mathcal{P}-hard in general,

The 1D and 2D PF sub-cases of p𝑝p-center problems are polynomially solvable with DP algorithms.
The 1D continuous p𝑝p-center is solvable in O​(n​log3⁡n)𝑂𝑛superscript3𝑛O(n\log^{3}n) time ,
whereas the time complexity in a 2D PF is in O​(p​n​log⁡n)𝑂𝑝𝑛𝑛O(pn\log n)  [ref]16.
The discrete p𝑝p-center problem in a 2D PF is solvable in O​(n​log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛O(n\log n) time and O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) space ,
whereas it is solvable in O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) time in 1D .
The Min-sum p𝑝p-radii problems, denoted also min-sum-diameter, are p𝑝p-center variants, where the covering balls may not be identical. It is a min-Sum-Max optimization, that we can compare to the
Max-Sum-min optimization with p𝑝p-dispersion-MSm.
Min-sum p𝑝p-radii is 𝒩​𝒫𝒩𝒫\mathcal{N}\mathcal{P}-hard in the general case and polynomial within a tree structure .
The 𝒩​𝒫𝒩𝒫\mathcal{N}\mathcal{P}-hardness is also proven even in metrics induced by weighted planar graphs

In a 2D PF, Min-sum p𝑝p-radii is solvable in O​(p​n2)𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛2O(pn^{2}) time with a DP algorithm [ref]16.
